title: Boy dragged out car and stabbed as parents collect kids from school at rush hour
text:

A teenage boy was stabbed in broad daylight as parents collected children from school nearby.

The teenager was punched through a car door before being pulled from the vehicle, dragged along the floor, kicked repeatedly and stabbed.

A witness picking her daughter up from nursery heard someone shout: "He's got a knife", WalesOnline reports.

Brothers Curtis Walker and Kane Walker were sentenced at Cardiff Crown Court on Friday for their roles in the attack, along with their 17-year-old co-defendant, who also cannot be named.

The court heard the incident happened in Cardiff at roughly 4.50pm on Thursday, July 4.

Roger Griffiths, prosecuting, said a local resident heard “shouting and swearing” outside his house.

The witness, who was working from home, looked out of the window and saw a group gathered around a white Ford Fiesta.

Prosecutors said he carried on working, then a few moments later heard someone shout they were going to call the police.

He saw another group walking towards the car and filmed the incident on his phone.

(Image: MEDIA WALES)

Judge Tracey Lloyd-Clarke said: “He could see as they approached that the incident was about to escalate and that violence was about to take place.”

The footage showed the victim, who was sitting in the passenger seat, being attacked while he was in the car, before being pulled out and dragged along the floor.

Prosecutors said Curtis Walker was heard to shout: “Give me the machete.”

Then his teenage co-defendant ran forward with a large kitchen knife and stabbed the victim.

Another woman, who had her young son in the car, was driving along the road and also witnessed the attack.

The court heard the complainant pulled a knife out after he was stabbed and subsequently did not cooperate with the police.

Mr Griffiths said it was a “sustained and repeated” assault, adding the machete used by the group was never recovered.

Curtis Walker, who had 21 previous offences on his record, answered “no comment” to all the questions put to him in his police interview.

The 19-year-old, from Trowbridge, admitted violent disorder and was found guilty of attempted wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm.

Hashim Salmman, defending, pointed out Curtis Walker did not have any previous convictions for violence and suggested his offending was “out of character” in that context.

He told the court his client did not kick the victim or hold the knife during the attack.

A pre-sentence report noted Curtis Walker’s father was violent and “extremely familiar with the criminal justice system”.

The defendant, who has now left the care of the local authority, was diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and oppositional defiant disorder.

Mr Salmman said his client was diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder at a young age after witnessing a family member being covered in petrol and set alight.

The court heard Curtis Walker was taken out of mainstream education and is currently working towards qualifications in carpentry.

His brother Kane Walker, who had 38 previous offences on his record, gave a prepared statement to the police, claiming he was acting in self-defence.

Prosecutors said the offence was committed just seven weeks after he was released from custody. Kane Walker, 20, from Roath, admitted violent disorder.

(Image: Media Wales Ltd)

Marian Lewis, defending, suggested his role was different from his co-defendants as he was “on the periphery” of the incident.

She said he was “clearly not a ringleader”, he was not armed and did not realise anyone else was carrying a weapon.

Ms Lewis told the court Kane Walker had a difficult upbringing, which lacked proper guidance, and he was influenced by his brother.

Prosecutors said the 17-year-old, who also gave a “no comment” interview, had previous convictions including assault, affray and assault occasioning actual bodily harm.

Rosamund Rutter, defending, said he entered his guilty plea at an early stage.

She drew the judge’s attention to a report from the youth offending team, outlining his learning disabilities and mental health problems, and a reference from his grandfather.

Ms Rutter said: "He does have the ability to turn his life around."

In her sentencing remarks, Judge Lloyd-Clarke noted the assault happened in broad daylight on a public street, where parents were collecting their children from school.

She said: "It is obvious that these offences are so serious that only immediate custody is appropriate."

Curtis Walker was sent to a young offender institution for five years, Kane Walker for two years and four months, and the teenager for three years and nine months.

Further defendants are due to be sentenced at the youth court.
description: Brothers Curtis Walker and Kane Walker were sentenced at Cardiff Crown Court on Friday for their roles in the attack on the teenage schoolboy
